description: Farah Stockman, a national correspondent with The Times, will return to Indianapolis to discuss the economic uncertainties that so many Americans face.
title: A Reporter Returns to Indianapolis to Discuss Jobs and the Economy
title_page: A Reporter Returns to Indianapolis to Discuss Jobs and the Economy - The New York Times
text:
Update: Read about our event in Indianapolis on Dec.7.
In October, The Times published a story of mine about Shannon Mulcahy, a woman who escaped domestic violence by becoming a steelworker at the Rexnord bearing plant in Indianapolis. Working at the factory gave her financial independence, a sense of identity and a chance to master one of the most dangerous, complicated and highly-paid jobs in the plant.
Then Shannon’s bosses announced that they were moving the factory to Mexico, throwing Shannon’s future into jeopardy. For more than seven months, I followed Shannon and several of her co-workers as the plant closed down and moved — piece by piece — to McAllen, Texas and Monterrey, Mexico.
I chronicled the workers as they agonized over whether to train their replacements for extra pay. Their decisions divided the plant and ended friendships.
My article asked — but could not answer — a question bigger than the Rexnord bearing plant: What does the future look like for workers like Shannon? At a time when automation and cheaper wages overseas threaten to displace more and more blue-collar workers, where do people without college degrees fit into the American economy?
